summary: Kevin Durant scored 27 points before taking the fourth quarter off and the Oklahoma City Thunder rolled past the error-prone New Jersey Nets on Wednesday night.

summary: After decades of civil war, and several years of tenuous peace, southern Sudan is preparing to decide whether to split from the north to form a separate nation.

summary: A two-hour trek from Midtown Manhattan to Brooklyn's Greenpoint in the midst of Sunday's big blizzard, as documented by WSJ photo editor Dustin Drankoski.

summary: The storm that struck the housing market has left many casualties -- lenders, builders, real-estate agents, mortgage-bond investors. Add to the list the comity of certain communities where residents live together, some paying their mortgages and homeowner-association fees, and some not.

summary: Hong Kong restaurateur and chef Tony Cheng has enjoyed a swift rise to the top of the city's food scene.

summary: As Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva prepares to step down from Brazil's highest office, he leaves a legacy whose downsides may undermine the very success that made him the most popular president ever in Latin America's biggest country.

headline: The Answer: Looking Good in Leather
summary: A leather jacket seems like a great idea. But there's a fine line separating the young, tough Marlon Brando and the middle-aged, overweight David Hasselhoff. How can you make sure you get it right?

summary: It's been a banner year for the Asian arts scene, with record auction sales, major gallery openings and the rising international renown of a handful of top Asian artists.

summary: Amid the preholiday quiet, options traders made a flurry of moves targeting shares in Anadarko Petroleum and MBIA.

headline: Small Cap Meant Big Rise This Year
summary: It has been a good year for the stock market. It has been a great year for small caps, as they more than doubled the gains of their larger brethren.

headline: Dow Treads Lightly Toward '11
summary: The Dow industrials shed 15.67 points, or 0.14%, to 11569.71 after reaching two-year highs, as trading volume remained light.

headline: Forget Black Swans, Find Ugly Ducklings
summary: Investing forecasts are for the birds, but we needn't face 2011 blindly, writes Brett Arends. While we can't predict next year's swans, we do know today's ugly ducklings. Here are five.

headline: Dollar Rally Loses Momentum
summary: The dollar couldn't sustain its early momentum after a batch of strong economic reports and slipped to a seven-week low against the yen and a record low against the Swiss franc.

headline: B&N Calls Nook Its Best Seller
summary: Barnes & Noble said its line of Nook e-readers has become the best-selling product in the company's nearly 40-year history.

headline: U.K. Finance Jobs Ramp Up
summary: The U.K.'s financial services sector took on more staff in the three months to October and plans to continue adding workers in the coming 12 months, a survey shows.

headline: Concert Ticket Sales Fizzle
summary: Revenue from concert tours declined by double-digits in 2010, a troubling sign for what has been one of the music industry's brighter spots.

headline: Oil Prices Duck Back Under $90 a Barrel
summary: Crude-oil prices fell below $90 a barrel after a government report showed U.S. oil supplies aren't falling as quickly as expected.

headline: Jobs Data Hurt Gold, but Silver Touches a Record
summary: Reports showing a stronger U.S. economy pressured precious metals prices, though silver and palladium prices set multiyear highs earlier in the session.

headline: FDIC Requires Banks to Make Changes in Quarterly Reports
summary: U.S. banks submitting quarterly reports on their financial conditions in January must make several changes due to new regulations.

headline: Argentina Reaches 80% Acceptance in 'Brady Bond' Swap
summary: Holders of more than 80% of Argentina's defaulted Brady bonds have accepted a debt-swap offer in exchange for a basket of U.S. dollar-denominated bonds and a cash payment. Analysts expect Argentina to make a bid to sell new bonds overseas in 2011.

headline: 3M Sued Over Water Pollution Claim
summary: Minnesota Attorney General Lori Swanson on Thursday sued 3M Co., claiming a chemical it used to make various products caused damage to ground and surface water, the St. Paul Pioneer Press reported on its website.

headline: Bud Drops Baseball Suit
summary: Anheuser-Busch reached a new sponsorship agreement with Major League Baseball and dropped a suit it filed against the league in November.

headline: Photos of the Day
summary: In today's pictures, German carolers gather, Oklahoma State celebrates a win, and a wallaby looks for a dry spot.

headline: Venezuela Unifies Exchange Rates
summary: Venezuela announced Thursday that it will once again change its exchange-rate regime by creating a flat rate of 4.30 bolivares per dollar starting Jan. 1, less than a year after the country gambled on a dual-rate structure that was supposed to offset skyrocketing inflation.

headline: Costs of Coal-Ash Rule Draw Fire
summary: Environmental groups are accusing the Obama administration of inflating the costs of a proposed rule that requires coal-fired power plants to manage ash that comes from burning coal.

headline: Argentina Boosts Wheat Forecast
summary: Excellent conditions through key development phases boosted Argentina's wheat yields and led the Buenos Aires Cereal Exchange to raise its forecast for total production by one million metric tons to 14.5 million tons.

headline: Ukraine Cuts Some Gas Deliveries to Poland
summary: Ukraine's Naftogaz will stop its natural-gas deliveries to Poland Jan. 1, Poland's gas monopoly said, adding that the stoppage won't affect the Polish economy.

headline: Losses for Europe's Last Full Day of 2010
summary: Most European stocks fell, as trading wound down ahead of the year end in the last full session of 2010.

headline: India, Iran Bank Officials to Meet
summary: India and Iran scrambled to end a deadlock over payments for crude oil. A delay in solving the issue has the potential to raise India's import bill, but Indian oil companies said they didn't expect any immediate supply shortages.

headline: New York News Photos of 2010
summary: The best news photos from Greater New York this year: a bomb scare in Times Square, a firefighter who resuscitated a puppy, storm damage in Staten Island, a Michael Jackson memorial in Brooklyn and more.

headline: Israel's Ex-President Convicted of Rape
summary: An Israeli court has convicted former President Moshe Katsav on two counts of rape, making a lengthy jail sentence possible for the former senior statesman.

summary: From a soapy circus elephant to a man in a panda costume asking to be punched, here's a look at some of the year's best culture photos from Greater New York.

headline: Air Safety Disappoints in 2010
summary: The number of airline accidents and passenger fatalities increased in 2010, while insurance claims have exceeded premiums, according to aviation consultants Ascend Worldwide.

headline: Japanese Yields Fall

summary: A powerful bomb exploded outside a court building in a central district of the Greek capital, but there were no immediate reports of injuries.

headline: Most Asia Markets Gain
summary: Most Asian stock markets ended higher, boosted by a rosy outlook for 2011, U.S. dollar weakness and firmer metal prices. Tokyo fell 1.1%.

headline: Brooklyn Townhouse with Musical Roots

summary: The 10 most notable homes of 2010 continues with this two-story penthouse that brings aspects of New York City's infrastructure along with the four natural elementsâearth, water, air and fireâinto its design.

summary: Secularists should recognize that the pope's fight is their fight.

headline: Favre to Redskins? So Wrong It's Right

headline: Higher MTA Fares, Tolls Kick In

summary: The International Monetary Fund has issued a stern warning to Pakistan to take measures to cut its spiraling budget deficit, according to a senior Pakistani government official.

summary: State and local tax revenues continue to recover as the economy improves, but remain below pre-recession peaks and are likely to face continued pressure in 2011.

summary: Fashion reporter Teri Agins answers readers' questions about clothes that fill out slim physiques.

summary: While U.S. entrepreneurs continued to struggle in 2010—facing tight credit markets and weak consumer spending—those problems paled in comparison to what business owners faced in the world's more troubled regions.

headline: Rove: Gitmo Is Not a Recruiting Tool for Terrorists
summary: The president is wrong to claim that it is. In fact, al Qaeda and its affiliates rarely mention the prison.

summary: Regional leaders sent to negotiate a solution to a standoff in Ivory Coast said they would give Laurent Gbagbo more time before forcing him out.

headline: Canada Slashes Business Levies

headline: Obama to Extend Hawaiian Vacation
summary: President Obama won't be returning to Washington until Jan. 4, extending his Hawaiian vacation after it was delayed by a busy lame-duck Congressional session.

headline: Blizzard's Impact Eases on Air Travel
summary: The East Coast travel mess eased as crews cleared snow from more airport runways and airlines dispatched extra planes to pick up travelers waiting to get in or out of New York, Philadelphia and Boston.

headline: China May Throw Wrench Into Oil Market
summary: China is expected to resume building its strategic oil reserves next year, a development likely to quicken the march to triple-digit oil prices.

headline: Sad Songs Say So Much
summary: Screening's of "Winter's Bone," "Little Murders" and a new documentary about Phil Ochs lead the calendar-flipping week at the city's repertory film houses.

headline: Forecast Threatens Winter Classic

headline: Wilderness Policy Stirs Anger
summary: An initiative to preserve more public lands as wilderness is stirring anger in the West, where ranchers, sportsmen and energy companies fear they will lose access to acreage they count on for their recreation and livelihood.

headline: U.S. Seeks Chief for New Agency
summary: White House adviser Elizabeth Warren and a top lieutenant are quietly asking business and consumer groups for names of people who might run the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

headline: Driver's-Seat View of a Changing City
summary: One of San Francisco's longest-serving taxi drivers discusses the hazards of New Year's Eve, how the city has evolved and what annoys cabbies most.

summary: New York is a city brimming with fashion editors, designers, models, celebrities and socialites. Here are five well-dressed women in their five favorite looks of the year.

headline: Andrew Flynn: Our 'Pragmatic,' 'Ebullient' Year of 'Austerity'
summary: Explaining the most-searched words of 2010.

headline: Cameron King of All He Surveys, For Now
summary: At the close of 2010, the consensus view is that David Cameron is now heading for a terribly tough year and deep unpopularity.

headline: Do James and Wade Work Better Alone?
summary: There's some statistical evidence this season that Dwyane Wade and LeBron James play better when one of them is on the hardwood and the other the bench.

summary: Scorching heat in South America is cutting harvest forecasts and helping propel crop prices to fresh two-year highs. Still, prices of corn, soybean and wheat crops remain well below 2008 peaks.

headline: World Watch
summary: Here is a selection of news from around the world from today's Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: The Book Makes the Expert
summary: Books are becoming popular marketing tools for self-employed professionals able to take advantage of new forms of publishing, including electronic publishing and print-on-demand.

headline: From WikiLeaks to Wedding Bells
summary: It was a year of doom and gloom and discovering what diplomats really think. But away from the diplomatic and economic turmoil, 2010 offered escape with iPads and a royal engagement.

headline: Noun, Verb or Adjective
summary: But rather than have everyone submit identical form letters, which might be disregarded by regulators,the industry had them fill out templates. One begins: "I am a…student at [INSTITUTION] studying [PROGRAM]." It then hits the industry's talking points and gives the student space to "[EXPLAIN ANY OTHER CONCERNS…]." By law, the department was required to read through all letters with original content. The process took over a month, pushing publication of the rule into 2011.

headline: N.J. Bridge Could Get a Lift for Ships
summary: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey wants to raise the Bayonne Bridge's roadway so big new cargo ships can get to its docks.

headline: A Steadier Lunchtime at Lafitte
summary: The chef of Lafitte Restaurant says he wants his eatery to be a place that people can go to for a working lunch or a leisurely afternoon meal.

summary: The New Era Pinstripe Bowl, the Big Apple's first bowl game in 48 years, brings back memories of the short-lived Gotham Bowl.

headline: Former Titan Has a Message for Giants
